title.narrative: Providing access to education to children impacted by Hawija military offensive

description.narrative:
The objective of the project is to strengthen resilience by providing access to education to highly vulnerable children in Shirqat and Hawija by ensuring safe and equitable education opportunities including conflict sensitive education and culturally appropriate learning to both IDP and host communities. The proposed project will enhance access to education by establishing additional locations for education and psychosocial support for children. Using existing schools will be prioritized, however if existing schools are inaccessible, the proposed project also enables PIN education teams to establish temporary learning spaces. The proposed project is designed to address the needs of out of camp IDPs and returnee and remainee children as the areas in and around Hawija become accessible. These communities will be identified by PIN Rapid Needs Assessments conducted initially in Shirqat and transitioning to Hawija. This approach will enable PIN to achieve the objectives laid out in the Hawija Reserve Allocation Strategy, IHPF and HRP. Reintegration of children into the formal school system will be done through community outreach, out of school children (OOSC) will be identified in the implementation locations and will be coached and supported by PIN education facilitators and PIN school supervisors to help OOSC in the process of registration into formal school system to ensure their (re)enrollment in school. This will be done with a close collaboration with the local DoE authority in place and with the school head masters’ coordination and support.
Given the increasing trend of displacement caused by the Hawiga offensive and the renewed access to Hawija and the surrounding area, 5,400 conflict affected children including IDPs, returnees, and remainees will benefit from quality and life-sustaining learning through non-formal education, psychological support and awareness sessions provided by trained educators. The proposed approach enables PIN to address out of camp needs stemming from both displacement and newly retaken areas comprising remainee and returning communities in Hawija,
The establishment of integrated Child Friendly Spaces and Temporary Learning Spaces (CFS/TLS) will greatly increase access to education as many schools in the target area are not yet reopened and will provide quality, conflict sensitive education to vulnerable children impacted by the ongoing Hawija offensive. Based on the urgent needs of children, special focus will be given to providing catch up classes to children as a means of transitioning to formal education over time and minimizing the impact of prolonged education disruptions. Additionally the project will target 108 adults with education experience including teachers to provide them with training on PSS and EiE. This training will directly support the psychosocial wellbeing and the education needs of children. It should also improve the quality of education provided to children as schools will begin instruction and lessons.
